stories.headline: President signs order, sets tariffs to EU, 68 others
stories.summary: President Donald Trump signed an executive order imposing tariffs on a wide range of trading partners, including the European Union and 68 other countries. The tariffs are part of a trade war expansion in response to complaints about unfair trade practices. Mexico was granted an additional 90-day negotiation period before tariffs take full effect. The administration cited the need to protect American industries and handle trade imbalances.

stories.headline: State to seek death penalty
stories.summary: Arkansas State Police announced plans to seek the death penalty for a man charged with killing a married couple at Devil's Den State Park. Prosecutors cited the severity of the killings over a weekend as justification. Andrew James McGann was arrested and charged with the deaths. The state police stated that all aggravating factors support the decision to seek the death penalty, and the case is proceeding accordingly.

stories.headline: Diocese to build seminary at fire site
stories.summary: The Diocese of Little Rock announced plans to build a new college seminary on the site of the St. Joseph Center of Arkansas, which was damaged by a fire in March. The lease for the center is set to end in 2026, and the Diocese is terminating its lease agreement, with the property to be used for the seminary and other future plans. The announcement was made by Bishop Anthony Basil Taylor.

stories.headline: Governor announces visits to Israel, UAE
stories.summary: Arkansas Governor Sarah Huckabee Sanders announced she will travel to Israel and the United Arab Emirates on a trade mission aimed at deepening economic ties. The trip will include meetings with Israeli agricultural and defense companies, as well as firms in the UAE. This is her fifth international trade mission since becoming governor and reflects Arkansas' expanding export markets.

stories.headline: Funeral held for slain officer
stories.summary: A funeral was held for New York Police Department officer Didarul Islam, with a hearse carrying his casket as the ceremony took place on White Plains Road in New York City. The event was marked by a strong law enforcement presence honoring the fallen officer.

stories.headline: Justice Department makes case for tariffs as trade war expands
stories.summary: The U.S. Justice Department officially defended the legality of President Trump's sweeping tariffs, arguing that the measures are necessary to counter unfair trade practices and protect American industries. This legal push aligns with the broader trade war strategy being implemented through tariffs on various countries. The department is working closely with trade officials to support these economic measures.

stories.headline: PR push called key in Dems’ map fight
stories.summary: The top Democrat in the U.S. House met with Texas state lawmakers to coordinate opposition against the planned Republican-led congressional map overhaul. The Democrat denied revealing their strategic plans but emphasized commitment to defending the current districts. House Minority Leader Hakeem Jeffries expressed that all options to protect the people of Texas would be considered. This comes amid tensions and efforts by Texas Democrats to resist the Republican majority's redistricting plans.

stories.headline: Kerr officials grilled over flood response
stories.summary: State lawmakers held a public hearing in Kerrville to review the July 4 flash flood response that killed more than 30 people. The hearing saw intense questioning of local officials from Kerr County and Upper Guadalupe River Authority regarding their initial response and preparedness. Lt. Gov. Dan Patrick described it as a very difficult situation and emphasized the importance of learning from the tragedy as flood relief is addressed in the ongoing Texas Legislature's special session.

stories.headline: Spending cap push aims to cut taxes
stories.summary: Governor Greg Abbott is pushing to lower property levies by imposing a spending cap that would make local officials face the same rules as the state. He aims to cut homeowners' property taxes by limiting how much cities and counties can increase their spending, arguing the measure would prevent tax increases and control population-driven spending growth. Abbott has campaigned on this issue before but seeks to advance it further in the new legislative session.

stories.headline: Hundreds of Fort Bend residents continue fighting concrete facility
stories.summary: Nearly a year after the completion of new housing developments, Fort Bend County residents protested against a proposed concrete crushing facility by filing a petition and holding meetings. Residents are concerned about the environmental impact and safety risks the plant would bring to the area. Local officials and environmental commissioners have been involved in discussions to address community concerns and permit applications related to the project.

stories.headline: Bands quit Spotify over AI weapons ties
stories.summary: Several artists have pulled their music from Spotify in protest against CEO Daniel Ek's recent investment in Helsing, a company involved in AI and fighter aircraft systems. The musicians, including Greg Saunier, express concern over the defense applications of AI technology and its funding from Spotify's leadership, leading to calls for more ethical considerations in technology investments by entertainment companies.

stories.headline: Russian attack kills 13, wounds 132
stories.summary: A Russian missile attack on a building in Kyiv, Ukraine, killed 13 people and wounded 132. Rescue efforts are ongoing amid the devastation.

stories.headline: Bird flu relief tops $230 million for state dairy farms
stories.summary: The federal government has provided more than $230 million in aid to California dairy farms to cover losses from bird flu, resulting in reduced milk production. This is the largest outbreak of avian influenza in U.S. history. Relief funds have been allocated to dairy farms across the state, including major producers like the Emerald Dairy Farm. The support aims to help the industry recover from the substantial financial impact caused by the disease and associated disruptions.

stories.headline: Utilities fought the removal of old power lines
stories.summary: Utilities including Edison and Southern California Edison opposed a state rule that would have forced them to remove old transmission lines suspected of igniting the Eaton fire, which killed 19 people and destroyed 9,400 homes. Despite records showing utilities' resistance, the regulation was weakened amid opposition from utility companies and lobbying efforts. Investigations into the fire and utility involvement continue.

stories.headline: Study: Pandemic aged brain faster, regardless of health
stories.summary: A new study shows that living through the COVID-19 pandemic caused accelerated brain aging even among people who were not infected by the virus. The study found that pandemic-related stressors such as prolonged isolation, reduced physical activity, and cognitive inactivity contributed to brain aging, although some effects may be reversible according to experts.

stories.headline: Trump delays Mexico tariffs
stories.summary: President Trump has delayed new tariffs on Mexican exports for 90 days as the two countries continue trade negotiations. The reprieve was announced after South Korean officials reached a deal with the U.S., and comes amid worldwide trade tensions. The delay aims to avoid disruption to major trading partners including Brazil, Canada, and India, as the president seeks to finalize trade agreements.

stories.headline: Annenberg’s final days saw bitter feud
stories.summary: In the final days of philanthropist Wallis Annenberg's life, a bitter dispute emerged among her closest friends and children regarding control over her medical decisions and inheritance. Allegations of wrongdoing, isolation, and withholding information led to court documents revealing family conflicts and plans to remove Annenberg's body from Century City for composting before a proper goodbye. The feud highlights ongoing tensions within wealthy families over legacy issues.

stories.headline: Nugent incident has Republicans pushing to end Capitol gun ban
stories.summary: Following a June incident where rocker Ted Nugent carried a gun inside the Michigan Capitol despite a firearms ban, Republican lawmakers introduced legislation to lift the ban on concealed pistols inside the Capitol Building. The proposed legislation would allow those with valid concealed pistol licenses to carry firearms within the Capitol, though open carry would remain banned. Supporters argue that the bill respects constitutional rights and improves safety and accountability, while opponents have raised concerns on enforcement and transparency in Capitol security.

stories.headline: Hotter summers could be making us sicker in unexpected ways
stories.summary: New research from California scientists shows that the heat may be making us sicker in unexpected ways. A study published in the journal Science Advances tracked emergency department visits and fatalities in the state over 11 years and found that deaths increased both in cold and hot temperatures. Emergency room visits steadily increased with temperatures, especially among older adults. The study indicates that temperature-related health impacts are broad, including cardiovascular and kidney diseases. The findings emphasize the need for more detailed analysis of temperature-morbidity relationships and interventions to mitigate heat-related health risks.

stories.headline: Stabbing suspect has bond increased to $1 million
stories.summary: A Grand Traverse County judge raised the bond for Walmart mass stabbing suspect Bradford James Gille to $1 million. Gille faces 11 counts of attempted murder and one count of terrorism for allegedly stabbing 11 people at a Walmart in Traverse City. Gille is held at the Grand Traverse County Jail and was arraigned with a $100,000 bond initially. Additional conditions include GPS tether and having contact with victims and their families. Gille’s history of mental illness and substance use was revealed, and reports show he has been hospitalized since age 14.

stories.headline: Bad weather and bad luck turned a summer day on Mount Katahdin into a hiker’s nightmare
stories.summary: Beata Kosc, stranded on the upper reaches of Mount Katahdin in Maine, survived a harrowing ordeal after strong winds and freezing rain threatened lives during a difficult hike on the Knife Edge trail. Kosc and her friend were unable to move for hours, with rescuers arriving late. Despite the terrifying conditions and risk of death, Kosc considered the experience a divine plan and expressed gratitude for surviving one of Maine’s most dangerous peak areas.

stories.headline: Bar advocates say raises fall far short
stories.summary: The state's criminal courts are impacted by weeks of unpaid overtime for public defenders advocating for the private attorneys who represent indigent clients. Advocates say recent pay raises are insufficient and the legislation proposed would worsely affect the number of salaried attorneys willing to work for the state public defender agency. Concerns include attorney shortages and increased workload, which undermine court efforts. The raising of pay has been criticized as inadequate by advocates pushing for more substantial support.

stories.headline: With mother held by ICE, two daughters in DCF care missing
stories.summary: Two teenage daughters of a woman detained by federal immigration agents are now missing after being placed in child protective services care amid protests and chaos during the mother’s arrest. Authorities have classified one daughter as endangered and an ongoing investigation is searching for both girls. The case highlights concerns around family separation and complexities within immigration enforcement and child welfare systems.

stories.headline: At Brown, deal fuels outrage over curtailing trans rights
stories.summary: Students at Brown University expressed alarm and outrage over the administration's decision to adopt a policy defining 'male' and 'female' based on biological criteria, which many say undermines transgender and nonbinary inclusivity. The decision follows a controversial agreement to restore biological orders on transgender participation in sports, provoking concern that it restricts queer and trans rights and alienates affected students. Advocates call the policy shameful and worry about its impact on vulnerable students.

stories.headline: Judge who ruled against Trump describes threats
stories.summary: A Rhode Island federal judge publicly shared the harassment and threats he has faced since issuing a ruling against the Trump administration's attempts to freeze federal funding. US District Judge John J. McConnell Jr. revealed that the intimidation includes expletive-laden voicemails and calls threatening his safety. Despite this, McConnell expressed a commitment to doing his judicial duties without sympathy, indicating the serious personal impact of his controversial decisions.

stories.headline: Flash in the night
stories.summary: A lightning bolt struck St. Joseph Sound where pilings remain under construction on the new Crystal Beach pier, nearly a year after Hurricane Helene tore through Pinellas County. The lightning is attributed to high humidity, lingering coastal moisture, and a seasonal pattern of storms fueled by daytime heating drift westward, often redeveloping near the coast overnight, according to the National Weather Service in Ruskin.

stories.headline: Fla. DOGE plans on-site audits
stories.summary: Florida's Department of Government Efficiency is set to conduct on-site audits of Pinellas and Hillsborough counties after finding an increase in their spending. Letters were sent to county leaders, requesting access to buildings, data systems, and personnel for inspections in early August. The audits come amid Governor DeSantis' push for transparency and accountability in government spending, following complaints about overuse of taxpayer funds in these counties.

stories.headline: Will the Phillies be able to reach a Clearwater stadium deal?
stories.summary: Negotiations between the Philadelphia Phillies and Clearwater and Pinellas County about remodeling their spring training site have hit an impasse. Although the team has proposed ambitious renovations, the sides have yet to agree on various proposals including a tax on short-term lodging and $40 million from Pinellas for upgrades. Local officials remain hopeful about finding a ballpark investment deal amid challenges reaching an agreement after multiple years of talks.

stories.headline: Floridians rush to install rooftop solar
stories.summary: Following the passage of the One Big Beautiful Bill Act, Florida residents are quickly installing rooftop solar panels before the expiration of the 30% tax credit at the end of December. U.S. Rep. Kathy Castor urges Tampa residents to act fast as demand has surged, causing delays in installation due to training requirements for installers. Business leaders and solar company officials are encouraging residents to add solar panels to save on energy costs amid recent extreme heat waves in Tampa Bay.

stories.headline: Hogan was recovering from surgery at time of death
stories.summary: Wrestling star Terry Bollea, known as Hulk Hogan, suffered a heart attack in Clearwater shortly after undergoing surgery. He died on July 24 at age 71 after collapsing at his Clearwater Beach home while using his 'doing therapy' radio communications. Firefighter paramedics who rushed him to hospital noted he was waiting to start dialysis. Paramedics administered drugs to treat high potassium and a kidney failure that could lead to cardiac arrest, but Hogan ultimately passed away.

stories.headline: Deadly Wave of Strikes Pummels Kyiv
stories.summary: A wounded man was seen outside his damaged home following a deadly wave of strikes in Kyiv, Ukraine’s capital. The attacks struck just east of the city amid escalating tensions after the U.S. imposed new sanctions, resulting in significant casualties including at least eight people killed.

stories.headline: Face to Face With the Park Avenue Gunman, but She Survived
stories.summary: Sebije Nelovic experienced a terrifying encounter with the Park Avenue gunman after decades of cleaning at 345 Park Avenue in Midtown Manhattan. On the day of the attack, she prepared for the day work but suddenly faced the shooter, narrowly escaping by fleeing and hiding in a closet while praying.

stories.headline: Implant Offers Hope of Easing Arthritis Agony
stories.summary: The Food and Drug Administration has approved a new implant device designed to help patients suffering from debilitating arthritis, particularly targeting those with severe inflammation and immune system issues. This device, known as the SetPoint System, works by modulating the immune response, potentially reducing the need for medications and improving patients' quality of life.

stories.headline: Being Trump’s ‘Friend’ Gains Little for Modi, Indians Say
stories.summary: Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India has sought closer ties with President Trump, hoping for beneficial relations. Despite the close rhetoric and efforts, India's public perception indicates little tangible gain from being allied with Trump, particularly amid controversies surrounding trade and international politics.

stories.headline: Gaza Hunger Gives Trump Familiar Test
stories.summary: As Gaza faces severe humanitarian crises amid ongoing conflicts and images of starving children emerge, President Trump encounters challenges similar to those faced by his predecessors in addressing complex Middle Eastern issues. Despite his attempts, the situation remains dire with persistent food shortages and exacerbating tensions.

stories.headline: Murky Pledges Throw Shadow On Trade Deals
stories.summary: President Trump's recent investment plans, including a $550 billion fund for investments in the U.S., have raised questions due to ambiguous pledges and discrepancies between trade partners. The complexities and lack of transparency have led experts to question the commitment levels and potential impacts on exports and economic relationships.

stories.headline: Loomer Targets a Fresh Round of U.S. Officials
stories.summary: Laura Loomer, a far-right activist known for her conspiracy theories, has initiated a new campaign targeting U.S. officials, including those associated with the Biden administration and the Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency. This wave of activism follows her past controversial actions and statements questioning various political entities.

stories.headline: Judges question Trump’s authority to impose tariffs
stories.summary: An appellate court panel in Washington is skeptical about President Donald Trump's legal authority to impose tariffs without congressional approval. During a hearing, judges questioned the administration's reliance on the International Emergency Economic Powers Act (IEEPA), highlighting concerns over executive overreach and the legal justification used for the tariffs, especially relating to trade deficits and national security.

stories.headline: Phone ban, other changes await
stories.summary: Alabama students returning to school will face new statewide regulations including a ban on phones, earbuds, and smartwatches during the entire school day. High school students will also experience changes to graduation requirements with a new career-focused diploma pathway starting with the class of 2026. The phone ban is part of the FOCUS Act aimed at improving student focus during school hours.

stories.headline: DU to study removal from drinking water
stories.summary: Decatur Utilities will start Phase 2 of a water treatment study targeting industrial contaminants called 'forever chemicals' by the end of the year. The $1.13 million study, conducted by Jacobs Engineering, is funded by a grant to reduce contaminants such as PFOA and PFOS. Testing of treatment technologies will determine the best options for Decatur's water treatment plant. DU spokesman Joe Holmes stated the project is proactive with water quality well below limits currently.

stories.headline: Getting ready for school
stories.summary: Decatur students are preparing for the upcoming school year, with events like the Decatur Youth Services' Back-to-School Jam taking place. The first day of school is Thursday, and classes will resume with some adjustments and resources such as free books being provided to students to help them start the year strong.

stories.headline: Jackson says he can provide change
stories.summary: Billy Jackson is running for mayor of Decatur after nearly three decades on the Decatur City Council. He aims to bring leadership and transparency to the mayor's office, and stresses his unique experience and education compared to other candidates who have business backgrounds. Jackson also wants to address long-standing issues in the community and has local legal backing from Carl Cole, who supports his institutional knowledge and commitment.

stories.headline: Heat deaths more likely if you live in these homes
stories.summary: Affordable homes in Metro Phoenix, such as mobile homes, trailers, and RVs, have been identified as the most dangerous for residents during extreme heat, with about 25% of indoor heat-related Valley deaths in 2024 occurring in these residences. While representing a smaller percentage of Phoenix's housing, these homes account for a disproportionate number of heat-related deaths, according to Maricopa County’s Department of Public Health and the Arizona Association of Manufactured Homes. This highlights the increased vulnerability of residents living in such housing.

stories.headline: AZ wants $760M from Trump
stories.summary: Arizona is seeking $760 million from President Donald Trump's budget to recoup costs spent on border barrier construction and enforcement in the state's southern border region. Governor Katie Hobbs sent a letter requesting reimbursement for roughly three-quarters of a billion dollars spent over four years, emphasizing the state's commitment to border security and combating drug and human trafficking. The request is tied to a sweeping law called the Big Beautiful Bill signed by Trump earlier in the month.

stories.headline: Report: U.S. inflation picks up during June
stories.summary: Inflation in the United States increased in June as tariffs boosted prices for imported goods like household furniture and recreation products. Despite this, consumer spending remained steady amid ongoing tariff talks and concerns from the Federal Reserve about future interest rate hikes. The personal consumption expenditures price index rose 0.3% in June, signaling inflation is diverging from the Federal Reserve's target and complicating economic expectations.

stories.headline: Boost for rural broadband
stories.summary: Two companies plan to invest millions over the next four years to expand and enhance rural broadband infrastructure in northeastern Arizona, aiming to improve internet access and connectivity for residents in these underserved areas.

stories.headline: Kelly sent to Rangers
stories.summary: The Arizona Diamondbacks traded pitcher Merrill Kelly to the Texas Rangers in the final hour before the trade deadline, marking a significant roster move for both teams during the season.

stories.headline: Perdue faces new PFAS contamination lawsuit
stories.summary: Perdue Farms is being sued by two Salisbury residents over drinking water contamination from so-called 'forever chemicals,' PFAS. The lawsuit alleges that Perdue Farms' operations contributed to PFAS pollution, prompting calls for a separate proposed class-action lawsuit to address the public health risks and environmental damage caused by these contaminants.

stories.headline: President signs order on new tariffs
stories.summary: President Donald Trump signed an executive order instituting new tariffs on a wide range of U.S. trading partners, effective August 7, as part of his strategy to strengthen the American economy and international alliances. The tariffs come after recent tariff-related activity and aim to balance trade with the U.S. and regional economies. The order was issued shortly after a discussion with Mexican President Claudia Sheinbaum, affecting 68 countries and the 27-member European Union, with the senior administration official stressing anonymity on the condition.

stories.headline: ChatGPT info can be used against you, AI leader warns
stories.summary: Sam Altman, CEO of OpenAI, cautioned the public about sharing sensitive information in AI chatbots like ChatGPT, warning that such data could potentially be used against users in legal settings. During a podcast, Altman emphasized the need for transparency around data use and the risks AI platforms pose to privacy and mental health. He called for regulations to limit data sharing and protect users from unintended consequences resulting from AI interactions.

stories.headline: A socialist surge? Analysts say Democrats challenging status quo
stories.summary: Political scientists in Maryland observe an increasing support among Democrats for self-described 'Democratic socialist' candidates, including some advocating for significant shifts such as a boycott of Israel and progressive policies. Candidates like Zohran Mamdani and Omar Fateh have gained prominence, with endorsements from groups such as the Minnesota Democratic-Farmer-Labor Party. While this trend challenges traditional party dynamics, it also faces criticism from establishment Democrats and provokes debate about the future direction of the party.

stories.headline: State launches investigation into Caroline County agency
stories.summary: The Maryland Department of Human Services has started an investigation into Caroline County Child Protective Services after concerns surfaced that CPS staff failed to respond adequately to calls about two children in need at a Federalsburg home. The investigation follows reports of law enforcement and community frustration over CPS response times and communication, with allegations of neglect and inadequate after-hours services. Caroline County State's Attorney Sloan Franklin has confirmed the probe and emphasized the seriousness of the issue.

stories.headline: Baltimore nonprofit empowers fathers, offers support and advocacy
stories.summary: Markus Trent, executive director of Fathers Fighting 4 Fathers, turned to professional mental health support and mentoring after losing his healthcare job and battling depression. The nonprofit helps fathers in Baltimore and beyond to connect, support each other, and access mental health resources and legal support. It organizes biweekly gatherings and advocacy events focused on fatherhood issues like reunitification, incarceration, and career services, helping fathers stay involved with their children and addressing systemic challenges.

stories.headline: Betting market odds on 2028 presidential election
stories.summary: Wes Moore states he is not running for president in 2028, but betting markets still suggest Maryland's governor has a strong chance of winning the Democratic nomination should he decide to run. This insight comes from an analysis of online betting trends and political speculation.

stories.headline: O's trade away 6 more players for prospects
stories.summary: The Baltimore Orioles continued their player trade activity before the trade deadline by trading six more players. This move is part of a strategy focused on building for the future by acquiring promising prospects. The trades involve players like Cedric Mullins and Ryan O'Hearn as the team reshapes its roster towards long-term development.

stories.headline: Preparing for a downpour
stories.summary: Baltimore City's Department of Transportation is storm-preparedness advancing, as seen with crews laying yellow bags filled with absorbent materials in strategic locations to prevent flooding during an upcoming storm. The efforts focus on protecting up to 1700 blocks around 35th Street and other vulnerable areas to mitigate water damage and ensure community safety during harsh weather conditions.

stories.headline: Roaring Debut Is Sign of IPO Revival
stories.summary: Shares of the software company Figma soared in their stock-market debut, rising 250% in one of the splashiest initial public offerings in years. The strong reception could signal a revival of IPO activity in the market, which had been slow. The stock opened high and showed strong buying interest from investors hungry for tech offerings.

stories.headline: Fear of Higher Prices Powers iPhone Sales, Lifting Apple Results
stories.summary: Apple iPhone sales exceeded Wall Street expectations in the June quarter as customers rushed to buy devices ahead of potential price increases due to tariffs. The company's price increases and the shift to higher-priced models helped boost revenue by about 3%, raising Apple's quarterly sales to $44.6 billion. The strong demand was also driven by a one-time tariff-related spending boost and broader market trends.

stories.headline: Trade Fight Reverses Gains for Millions
stories.summary: Export manufacturing in countries like Indonesia has helped narrow wealth gaps with Western nations, but President Trump's trade policies are reversing some of these gains. The imposition of tariffs and trade restrictions have led to factory closures and economic hardships for many, threatening to undo progress made in developing nations that rely on export-driven growth.

stories.headline: Ford’s Made-in-U.S. Strategy Hurts It in Trump’s Tariff War
stories.summary: Ford Motor's strategy to manufacture most of its vehicles in the U.S. makes the company vulnerable in the ongoing tariff war since it relies heavily on imported materials subject to duties. This disadvantages Ford compared to competitors who manufacture vehicles abroad, as rising tariffs on imports are increasing production costs. Ford executives emphasize their commitment to American manufacturing despite the challenges.

stories.headline: President Moves To Raise Tariffs Aug. 7
stories.summary: The U.S. government will raise tariffs on nearly all its trading partners starting August 7. The order signed by President Trump extends the deadline for deals by six days and aims to update the Harmonized Tariff Schedule for higher levies. The tariffs are expected to raise costs on about 100 countries and protect U.S. interests on Customs and Border Protection matters.

stories.headline: Russian Barrage on Kyiv Kills at Least 13
stories.summary: A missile-and-drone barrage on Kyiv destroyed an apartment building, leaving 13 people dead, including a 6-year-old boy. This attack caused the highest number of children injured by a single strike in the war to date.

stories.headline: E-books look for a lifeline
stories.summary: Claire Holahan and millions of Americans rely on library e-books, which face budget cuts under a congressional proposal to eliminate federal funding for libraries and museums. The loss of e-books through local libraries could impact many readers who depend on this access, highlighting concerns over the future availability of digital library resources.

stories.headline: Maxwell's privileged life, where it went awry
stories.summary: Ghislaine Maxwell, now in prison and awaiting trial for sex trafficking, seeks freedom while details emerge about her privileged background and connections, including to Jeffrey Epstein. She is under scrutiny for her role in recruiting and abusing underage girls, with many watching to see if she will receive a pardon.

stories.headline: Creepy hordes of tarantulas just looking for some love
stories.summary: Thousands of tarantulas will be crawling across the Southwest and West in the coming months searching for mates. Scientists advise hikers and campers to leave the tarantulas alone, as these wild animals pose no threat and are part of the natural wonder of the area during their mating season.

stories.headline: Dems look for a face in the crowd
stories.summary: As the 2028 Democratic presidential class emerges, the field remains uncertain and fuzzy, with contenders ranging from prominent governors and senators to less-defined stars. The race is shaping into a full-employment project for Democrats with various political philosophies, while former Vice President Kamala Harris has halted her California governor campaign and left the door open for a White House bid in 2028.

stories.headline: Epstein, Maxwell grand jury witnesses were all investigators
stories.summary: Witnesses who testified before federal grand juries in New York investigating sex-trafficking allegations against Jeffrey Epstein and Ghislaine Maxwell were revealed to be law enforcement members, including an FBI agent and a New York City police detective who belonged to the FBI's child exploitation and human trafficking task force. Despite no victims testifying in the grand jury, later testimonies were consistent with recorded accounts from these agents. The department also disclosed recent filings criticizing former President Donald Trump and conspiracy theories.

stories.headline: Newsom wants redistricting election in November
stories.summary: Governor Gavin Newsom announced plans to approve new congressional maps to redistrict the state and combat similar efforts in Texas. The special election would be held on the first Tuesday of November, with maps in effect for 2026, 2028, and 2030 elections. Newsom emphasized the need to prevent Texas' Governor Greg Abbott from influencing redistricting and expressed commitment to maintaining control of U.S. House seats for California Republicans and Democrats through fair maps.

stories.headline: DOJ sought to defend trade war ahead of sweeping tariffs
stories.summary: The Justice Department scrambled to defend the legality of President Donald Trump's sweeping tariffs just one day before he was set to expand his highly contested global trade war with new duties on the United States' closest trading partners. A federal appeals court raised questions about the financial stakes and legal risks for the White House as it prepared to impose higher rates and implement new trade deals without Congress' explicit approval. The legal dispute started when businesses and states challenged the administration's authority to impose such tariffs.

stories.headline: Over 150,000 federal workers accepted resignation incentives
stories.summary: The Trump administration paid roughly 154,000 federal employees to leave through resignation incentives, marking the largest reduction in the modern federal workforce. The government employed around 2.3 million nonmilitary workers at the start of the year. These incentives aimed to downsize the federal workforce early and involve exchanging years of pay for early resignation, but don't account for thousands fired or laid off. This disclosure provides the most comprehensive government data on workforce reductions under Trump and Musk's leadership.

stories.headline: Fearing war with Russia, Finland hardens NATO frontier
stories.summary: In response to rising tensions and recent attacks linked to Russia, Finland is rapidly strengthening its border defenses as it prepares to join NATO. The country is building an imposing barbed-wire-topped fence along a once-bustling section of its border with Russia, which was closed amid accusations of Russian weaponized migration. Finnish army reservist Janne Latto stresses the urgency of readiness as Finland bolsters its military presence, recalling echoes of past conflicts and supporting the NATO alliance.

stories.headline: Schools prep for ban on cellphones
stories.summary: New York State is preparing to implement a "bell-to-bell" ban on cellphones and other internet-enabled devices in public schools starting this September. While the exact enforcement details are to be finalized by individual school districts, this initiative is part of the newly passed "Distraction Free Schools" policy. Currently, about 55% of school districts have proposed plans consistent with this ban, aiming to reduce distractions and improve student focus during school hours.

stories.headline: Winners selected for Tompkins ‘I Voted’ stickers
stories.summary: Two young artists from Tompkins County have won top honors in the 2025 "I Voted" sticker contest aimed at encouraging youth engagement in democracy. Sevy Stiglitz, a fourth grader, and Olivia Casselberry, a seventh grader, created winning designs featuring dogs in outdoor settings. Their stickers will be distributed this fall, with the local elections board and community leaders praising their artwork and civic participation, viewing the initiative as a success in promoting voter turnout and awareness.

stories.headline: Soros implicated in Clinton plot in Trump-Russia hoax
stories.summary: Newly declassified Justice Department documents implicate left-wing donor George Soros in an FBI plot to spread Trump-Russia collusion allegations before the 2016 election. The documents also expose material supporting the claim that Hillary Clinton's campaign aimed to demonize Putin and Trump. These revelations show attempts to mislead U.S. publications and distract from Clinton's own legal issues.

stories.headline: Republican Sliwa gaining ground as Democrats split vote for mayor
stories.summary: Curtis Sliwa, founder of the Guardian Angels, is emerging as a frontrunner in the New York mayoral race following a Democratic split. He currently holds about 30% of the vote, close to the leading Democrat Zoe Mannix. Though Sliwa disagrees with former President Trump, Democrats are struggling with internal divisions over the incumbent. Sliwa is known for his distinctive red hat and strong local support.

stories.headline: Tiny goblins are grinning ear to ear as Labubu toy craze hits local area
stories.summary: A collectible toy craze originating from China has hit the Washington area, with Labubus — small goblin-like figures — becoming highly popular among collectors. The toys have spread via malls, Bethesda, Tysons, and other local outlets. These figures have also gained attention on social media platforms like TikTok, where collectors share their enthusiasm and hunting experiences.

stories.headline: Feds break up arms plot to equip violent Mexico cartel
stories.summary: Federal prosecutors charged a Bulgarian man with trafficking missiles, anti-personnel mines, and anti-aircraft weapons to Mexican drug cartels. The man, Peter Mirchev, allegedly bribed officials in African nations to divert shipments to cartel clients. Authorities are pursuing further arrests and trace investigations related to arms violations concerning the Jalisco New Generation Cartel and other violent operations.

stories.headline: Army tank too heavy to fly, too pricey to fix
stories.summary: The Pentagon is grappling with the issue of the M10 Booker, an armored vehicle intended as the U.S. Army's first new major combat weapon in decades. The tank is too heavy for paratrooper units and too expensive to maintain, resulting in the cancellation of the production contract and plans to send 30 units to storage. The Army is exploring alternatives and improvements to meet operational needs.

stories.headline: Wish list for new school construction grows longer; only a few will be funded
stories.summary: Maine schools have submitted a priority list for infrastructure projects, highlighting Bath, St. Agatha, and Old Orchard Beach. However, only a fraction of these ambitious projects — which cover building conditions and facility issues — are likely to be approved. A commission is also exploring ways to address critical infrastructure needs in the future.

stories.headline: As international conflicts rage, camp in Maine sows connection
stories.summary: The Seeds of Peace camp in Maine brings together young people from regions affected by conflict, providing a peaceful environment to foster dialogue, leadership, and reconciliation. Among them is Kiara, a first-generation American who shares her experiences amid political tensions involving ICE raids. The program aims to counter fear and division through understanding and community building.

stories.headline: Maine's referendum questions at a glance
stories.summary: The Secretary of State's Office has announced the order of two statewide referendum questions to appear on the fall ballot: one addressing voter ID requirements, and the other concerning a red flag law allowing courts to temporarily prohibit individuals from having dangerous weapons. These questions aim to impact voting procedures and public safety regulations.

stories.headline: Man who alleged abuse by priest at Maine Maritime gets settlement
stories.summary: Neal Gumpel, who alleged sexual abuse by a Jesuit priest at Maine Maritime Academy in the 1970s, has reached a settlement agreement. Gumpel said the abuse led to lifelong struggles, but he has spent years seeking validation. The settlement was announced by the New York Province of the Society of Jesus and Gumpel, though some family members reportedly disagree with his account.

stories.headline: 3 who taught at seminary are fired
stories.summary: The Catholic Church in southeast Michigan, led by Archbishop Edward Weisenburger, has fired three professors at Sacred Heart Major Seminary who were critical of Pope Francis. The dismissals have caused unrest among students and other faculty. Weisenburger, seen as a more conservative figure compared to his predecessor Archbishop Allen Vigneron, is removing teachers who were perceived as dissenters, reflecting ongoing tensions within the church over ideological differences.

stories.headline: Ford teases ‘Model-T moment’ on way
stories.summary: Ford Motor Co. CEO Jim Farley announced that the company will reveal its future electric vehicle strategy on August 11, calling it a 'Model-T moment' intended to position Ford to compete effectively against the Chinese EV market. This announcement hints at Ford's plans to introduce new vehicles featuring advanced technology, efficiency, and space benefits, underpinning a major transformation in its business.

stories.headline: A Bodega With Snacks, Tattoos
stories.summary: Detroit artist Sofia Sanchez launched a new project in Detroit combining a tattoo shop and a bodega, drawing inspiration from Puerto Rican culture. The launch event coincided with Puerto Rican pride celebrations in San Juan and offered a variety of food and cultural experiences. The bodega offers snacks, beverages, and a unique tattoo service, blending traditional convenience store offerings with local art and culture.

stories.headline: State makes first-ever ban from carbon market
stories.summary: Washington's Department of Ecology has banned Climate Care Innovations (CCI) from selling carbon allowances after the company tried to sell 'fishy' carbon allowances that were not part of the regulated market. The state remains confused about CCI's claims and cautions investors, as the first-ever ban aims to protect the integrity of Washington's carbon market.

stories.headline: Trump sets new tariffs for much of the world
stories.summary: President Donald Trump signed an executive order imposing new tariffs on a broad range of U.S. trading partners, effective August 7. This move is part of a broader trade agenda aimed at enforcing American economic and alliance policies that have developed over decades. The tariffs come after a period of increased trade-related activity and international negotiations.

stories.headline: Blue Angels roar back to Seafair
stories.summary: The Blue Angels performed a practice flight over Lake Washington near Genesee Park in preparation for the Seafair Weekend Festival, with shows scheduled for Friday, Saturday, and Sunday during the Boeing Seafair Air Show. The festival also features a new DIY wakeboarding competition called Can You Ride It?

stories.headline: Amazon sales, profits strong, but its outlook is uncertain
stories.summary: Amazon reported strong sales and profits for the second quarter, with $167.7 billion in revenue and $18.2 billion in profit, driven by increased customer spending between April and June. However, the company's outlook is uncertain as Wall Street remains nervous, with analysts expecting a gloomy profit forecast for the upcoming quarter amid broader economic concerns.

stories.headline: For M's fans, Suarez deal offers hope, good vibes
stories.summary: The Seattle Mariners have made a significant trade acquisition by bringing in Eugenio Suárez from the Arizona Diamondbacks, energizing fans with promise and positivity. The trade changes the tone for the Mariners, who have also faced challenges recently. Suárez's arrival marks a hopeful turning point for the team heading into the season.

stories.headline: Recession? TikTok says yes, economists are not so sure
stories.summary: Lady Gaga topping the charts and fashionistas' trends contrast with social media discussions predicting an impending recession in the U.S., notably on TikTok where users use clues like Coke bottle sales as signs of economic downturn. Economists remain cautious, emphasizing that such social media signals should be considered carefully.

stories.headline: Pilot killed when small plane crashes near I-65
stories.summary: A small plane crash behind a Circle K gas station near Main Street and I-65 in Greenwood resulted in the death of the pilot, Anh-Thu Nguyen. Nguyen, who aimed to be the first Vietnamese woman to complete a solo flight around the world, died when her plane crashed on July 30. The crash did not involve an explosion or fire. The Federal Aviation Administration and National Transportation Safety Board are investigating the incident.

stories.headline: Councilor Roberts won’t be charged
stories.summary: Fishers police have decided not to file charges against Indianapolis City-County Councilor Nick Roberts following an allegation of sexual assault by a young woman. After investigation, authorities found a lack of evidence and did not pursue charges. Roberts, who has admitted to kissing the woman but denies any wrongdoing, was supported by the Indiana Democratic Party during the process.

stories.headline: Woman was trying to fly solo around the world
stories.summary: Anh-Thu Nguyen, a 44-year-old pilot aspiring to be the first Vietnamese woman to fly solo around the world, tragically died after her small plane crashed in Greenwood. Nguyen, a 2015 Purdue graduate and aviation nonprofit founder, embarked on this journey to inspire Asian female pilots and aerospace engineers. The crash occurred shortly after she took off from a nearby airport, and investigations by the FAA and National Transportation Safety Board are ongoing.

stories.headline: Wreck occurred behind a Circle K in Greenwood
stories.summary: Businessman Frank Williams reported witnessing a small plane crash behind a Circle K gas station near Interstate 65 in Greenwood. He observed the pilot trying to bank the aircraft to avoid an obstacle before the plane crashed into a hill. Emergency responders quickly arrived on the scene. The identity of the pilot, Anh-Thu Nguyen, was confirmed by the Johnson County coroner. Authorities continue to investigate the incident.

stories.headline: Kohberger waived appeals in plea deal — but options remain
stories.summary: Bryan Kohberger, sentenced to four life terms without parole in a high-profile quadruple stabbing case, waived his right to appeal the first-degree murder convictions and an additional felony burglary conviction as part of a plea agreement. However, District Court Judge Steven Hippler mentioned not all appeal opportunities had been relinquished. The case remains complex with further legal options potentially available.

stories.headline: ‘Very special’ homes for sale next to Hyde Park
stories.summary: Two historic homes on 13th Street in Boise’s North End, near the Hyde Park district, are being listed for sale. Both properties are over a century old and have unique architectural features, including one home painted a distinct blueish-gray with maroon and off-white trim dating back to 1896, and the other a blue four-bedroom house from 1910. These homes are highly sought after, with prices at $1.3 million and $800,000 respectively, attracting significant interest from buyers in the market.

stories.headline: 'Bench bunnies': Boise neighborhood has a longtime rabbit problem
stories.summary: Residents of the Boise Bench neighborhood, especially around Ryan O’Leary’s yard, are dealing with an overpopulation of 'bench bunnies,' deserting domestic rabbits that have become feral over the last 40 years. These wild rabbits are causing issues such as eating flower beds and scaring dogs. The problem is linked to the area's development and natural predators declining. Community members and the Idaho Humane Society are concerned about the growing rabbit population and its impact on local residents.

stories.headline: She gave birth at a Boise hospital. This is what it cost her
stories.summary: Josie Last gave birth to her first baby at Saint Alphonsus Regional Medical Center in Boise and was surprised when the hospital bill was $6,000, double what their insurer had estimated. Despite an uncomplicated delivery, the charges included separate room and board fees for both mother and newborn, even though they shared a room. This billing experience highlights the complexities and challenges new parents in America face with hospital billing transparency and costs.

stories.headline: Nations scramble ahead of deadline
stories.summary: As President Donald Trump's dramatic tariff hikes approach, countries including Mexico scramble to finalize trade frameworks aimed at mitigating the tax effects on goods and preparing for the unknown. Mexico secured an extra 90 days to negotiate a trade agreement with the U.S., extending the tariff deadline and allowing time to address tariff rates that could impact trade. Mexican leader Claudia Sheinbaum noted ongoing efforts to build a long-term trade agreement through dialogue.

stories.headline: 'No one was in charge' Hearing reveals absent officials, fractured emergency help
stories.summary: A hearing revealed that during the Hill Country floods in Texas, several local officials were absent and leadership was lacking, leading to fractured emergency response. Testimony highlighted that Kerr County Judge Rob Kelly was not present during critical days of the flooding, and communication breakdowns and poor cellphone service hindered rescue efforts. Officials noted the absence of a coordinated local government response after the flood, which resulted in delayed assistance and raised concerns among lawmakers.

stories.headline: Dems gear up to fight new map
stories.summary: House Minority Leader Hakeem Jeffries has vowed to help derail the GOP's plan to redraw Texas districts, criticizing the Republican-driven redistricting plan that aims to eliminate five congressional seats held by Texas Democrats. Jeffries emphasized the importance of allowing Texans to choose their representatives and voiced concerns that the special session focusing on redistricting could undermine quality of life and affordable health care in the state.

stories.headline: Weed arrests may see an increase
stories.summary: Dallas police have made significantly fewer arrests for lower-level marijuana possession between November and June due to voter-backed city ordinances that decriminalized small amounts of cannabis. However, arrests for small possessions less than 4 ounces declined overall, but data indicate that arrests for some demographic groups may be rising. Efforts to override the voter-backed ordinances continue, creating an ongoing debate about marijuana possession enforcement within the city.

stories.headline: Leaders question Dorsey on benefit law
stories.summary: San Francisco Supervisor Matt Dorsey faces criticism from the LGBTQ+ community after suggesting the repeal of a city law that guarantees equal contract benefits for domestic partnerships. Dorsey, who is gay, asked city officials to estimate the cost to taxpayers of the Equal Benefits Ordinance, a 1996 law that prohibits such discrimination. The issue is stirring debate about equal rights in the city.

stories.headline: Homeless shelters paused in 2 districts
stories.summary: The San Francisco Board of Supervisors voted to place a moratorium on all new homeless shelters or behavioral health facilities in the Tenderloin and South of Market districts. The goal is to spread those services throughout the city. The board voted 9-2 to pass a bill by Supervisor Bilal Mahmood that imposes the moratorium and encourages shelters and services to be located based on neighborhood need.

stories.headline: Eames Institute museum expands footprint
stories.summary: A nonprofit dedicated to the legacy of midcentury designers Ray and Charles Eames is buying property in Marin County to create a global art and design museum expected to attract 200,000 visitors yearly. The Eames Institute of Infinite Curiosity is redeveloping the former Birkenstock campus in Novato, known for its unique roofline and location. The building will be redesigned to include office space, retail, culinary offerings, and outdoor sculpture gardens and plazas, aiming to create a magical destination.

stories.headline: Rare photos reveal Dead through formative years
stories.summary: A new book by rock ’n’ roll photographer Jim Marshall showcases rare photos of the Grateful Dead from their early years, coinciding with the band’s San Francisco weekend shows. Marshall took about 10,000 pictures of the band in various venues in their hometown, including Golden Gate Park and the Panhandle. His images capture the musicians’ essence and their legendary status in rock history.

stories.headline: U.S. envoys to assess aid situation in Gaza
stories.summary: U.S. special envoy Steve Witkoff arrived in Israel to discuss worsening humanitarian issues in Gaza amid ongoing violence, with over 90 Palestinians killed recently. Efforts to get aid into the region have been complicated by the conflict. Witkoff and Ambassador Mike Huckabee will inspect aid distribution centers as parts of a larger mission to assess and improve the aid flow into the Gaza Strip.

stories.headline: Pa. joins suit that would end attempt to halt funds
stories.summary: Pennsylvania Governor Josh Shapiro has joined a lawsuit with nearly 200 other states opposing a Trump administration rule aimed at cutting Medicaid funding for Planned Parenthood under the 'One Big Beautiful Bill.' The suit argues that the administration lacks proper authority to enforce the rule and that it threatens vital health centers across the country. The legal battle has potential widespread implications for healthcare access, especially for low-income Americans relying on Planned Parenthood services.

stories.headline: Building closure hearings draw low turnout
stories.summary: Across the Pittsburgh Public Schools district, public hearings on potential school closures have been met with low attendance. Despite frustrations among parents, students, and teachers, fewer than 100 people attended hearings for nine schools under closure consideration. The closure proposal affects several schools including Miller PreK-5 campuses, with only minimal attendance at these hearings. The trend shows a decline in public engagement as the district moves forward.

stories.headline: Nations facing boost in tariffs
stories.summary: President Donald Trump signed an executive order that will introduce new tariffs on a broad set of U.S. trading partners starting August 7. This move is part of Trump's strategy to reshape trade policies and protect American industries. The order caps the tariff rate increases at 15% for certain countries and 50% for Lesotho. Countries affected include Taiwan, Pakistan, Israel, and others. These tariffs have sparked debates about their long-term impact on the global economy and trade relations.

stories.headline: Trash collection delays roil city
stories.summary: Residents and city leaders in Pittsburgh are facing core service delays in trash and recycling collection due to an aging fleet of garbage trucks, with half of the vehicles inactive and many kept in garages. City Council members are expressing concerns about the service degradation especially in various neighborhoods including West End, Hill District, parts of Oakland, and Beechview.

stories.headline: MAYOR’S TEAM FLOATS 26 MONEYMAKING IDEAS TO PLUG CITY’S $1.12B BUDGET DEFICIT
stories.summary: The mayor's team proposes 26 different ideas to generate revenue to address Chicago's $1.12 billion budget deficit, aiming to improve the city's financial health.

stories.headline: Chicago air quality was world’s worst on Thursday thanks to wildfire smoke
stories.summary: Chicago experienced the worst air quality in the world on Thursday due to smoke from nearby wildfires, causing concern among residents and health officials.

stories.headline: RACE ON TO SUCCEED DAVIS AS HE OPTS TO STEP ASIDE
stories.summary: 15-term U.S. representative Davis chooses not to run again and endorses La Shawn Ford for the seat, while at least eight other candidates are preparing to compete for the position.

stories.headline: LOLLAPALOOZA LIFTOFF
stories.summary: Reviews from Day 1 of Chicago's annual four-day music extravaganza highlight performances by a strong lineup of hometown talent, showcasing vibrant energy and enthusiasm among attendees.

stories.headline: Lawsuit targets stadium law
stories.summary: Two Republican lawmakers and a taxpayer advocate filed a lawsuit challenging a new Kansas City sports team law. They argue the law enabling stadium subsidies is unconstitutional and should be nullified, focusing on proposed sweeteners related to stadium subsidies and concerns over property tax impacts. The lawsuit aims to stop financial support measures approved by the Missouri legislature that some see as costly and unfair to taxpayers.

stories.headline: Nations scramble to reach trade deals with US
stories.summary: Amidst President Donald Trump's recent tariff hikes, countries worldwide are rushing to finalize trade agreements with the US. Ongoing negotiations aim to avoid further tariff increases, with Mexican leader Claudia Sheinbaum highlighting progress in talks. The scramble reflects global economic concerns about escalating tariffs and their impact on trade relationships and markets.

stories.headline: Green's checks under scrutiny
stories.summary: St. Louis Mayor Cara Spencer vows to investigate how former Comptroller Darlene Green ended up reapplying on the city's payroll and receiving both a paycheck and a pension check. Spencer and new comptroller Donna Baringer are addressing concerns about potential clerical errors or more serious issues related to Green's payments, which could have broader implications for city departments and financial controls.

stories.headline: Page's indictment unprecedented
stories.summary: St. Louis County Executive Sam Page faces what is likely the first criminal charge against a county executive under a Missouri law prohibiting the use of public money for political purposes. Experts warn this case may set a new precedent as it involves allegations of using state resources for political campaign mailers, potentially impacting political entities like cities, schools, and libraries. Page is charged with two counts of election offenses and felony counts of stealing, carrying significant legal implications.

stories.headline: Whelan climbs 'steep hill' trying to rebuild his life
stories.summary: Paul Whelan, returning to American soil for the first time in over a year after his release from a Russian prison, is facing the challenge of rebuilding his life amidst bureaucracy and personal struggles. Whelan is part of a group of returned detainees dealing with the aftermath of their detainment, including adjusting to normal life and navigating government and employment issues. Arrested during a friend's wedding in Moscow in 2018 and convicted as a spy, Whelan served five years before being part of a historic prisoner exchange in 2024. He now lives with his parents in Manchester, Michigan, having lost his home in Novi.

stories.headline: $205M in earmarks sought for state projects
stories.summary: Spending bills moving through the U.S. House include more than $205 million earmarked for about 160 Michigan projects, including funding for a new patrol helicopter for Oakland County and cleanup of toxic chemicals in local harbors. While the appropriations process faces uncertainty, lawmakers are working to secure federal funding for these projects. Some lawmakers caution optimism, noting that no earmarks were included in the final 2025 funding bills yet, but funding proposals continue to develop.

stories.headline: Hillsdale curriculum powers Plymouth charter school
stories.summary: Ivygood Classical Academy in Plymouth is one of two classical education schools in Michigan using a curriculum, resources, and support provided by Hillsdale College. The charter school, opened six years ago, offers an alternative to traditional education with a focus on Greek and Latin traditions, modern architecture, and classical learning. The academy has seen rapid growth and its supporters appreciate the unique educational approach provided by Hillsdale's curriculum.

stories.headline: Feds pay over 154K people not to work
stories.summary: The Trump administration's deferred resignation program has resulted in the federal government paying more than 154,000 employees to not work, according to newly reported numbers. These buyouts and administrative leave orders, effective through the end of the fiscal year 2025, aim to reduce government size but have raised criticism for wasting taxpayer money by paying employees who do not work while others remain on leave or retire. Officials acknowledge uncertainty about long-term payroll savings from the program.

stories.headline: Power peaks top last summer
stories.summary: The Tennessee Valley Authority reported a peak power demand for the summer this week, marking the third peak in July alone, surpassing last summer's record. TVA met 31,888 megawatts of demand Wednesday amid high temperatures across its seven-state region, reflecting increased electricity needs. TVA operates the nation's largest public power system and is expanding power plants to meet growing demand fueled by regional population growth and AI development.

stories.headline: US envoy arrives in Israel as humanitarian crisis worsens
stories.summary: U.S. President Donald Trump's special envoy Steve Witkoff arrived in Israel to discuss the worsening humanitarian crisis in Gaza amid increasing Palestinian casualties. At least 91 Palestinians have died and over 600 were wounded in the past 24 hours. The Gaza Health Ministry reported significant deaths awaiting food and aid in northern Gaza. Witkoff and Ambassador Mike Huckabee will inspect food distribution in Gaza to address the escalating situation. The ongoing conflict and blockade have exacerbated medical shortages and civilian suffering.

stories.headline: No clear picture on speed cameras
stories.summary: Chattanooga is moving toward installing automated speed cameras in school zones despite legal uncertainties. Three months after the announcement, only some cameras have been installed with more planned. The cameras aim to improve safety by reminding drivers to reduce speed, particularly around schools during peak hours. While Tennessee law allows review of video footage, police have not yet assigned officers to monitor camera violations and are currently relying on other enforcement systems. A full-time position may be created for dedicated review in the future.

stories.headline: Vaccination rates fall for nation’s children
stories.summary: U.S. kindergarten vaccination rates have dropped overall compared to last year, with an increase in exemptions reaching an all-time high, according to federal data. The exemption rate rose to 4.1%, and 92.5% of 2024-25 kindergarteners received required vaccines although this is slightly lower than before COVID-19. The decrease raises concerns of potential disease outbreaks. The vaccination numbers were posted as the U.S. experiences its worst year for measles spread in over three years.

stories.headline: Girl's death exposes cracks in child protection system
stories.summary: Pepper Mogle witnessed her granddaughter Missy for the last time before Missy, a 5-year-old girl, died after suffering severe child abuse. Missy's mother, Chloe Spencer, and her stepfather, Daniel Spencer, have been charged with murder. The case raised questions about the child protection system and how Missy was left vulnerable despite reports and interventions. The tragic death has sparked public outrage and scrutiny on the system's effectiveness.

stories.headline: Palms West nurse beaten in Feb. to return home, facing long road
stories.summary: Leelamma Lal, a 67-year-old nurse who was nearly beaten to blindness by a hospital patient in February, is set to return home on August 2. This will be the first time since the attack that she will be in her Royal Palm Beach house, where she raised her children and studied to become a nurse. The attack happened at HCA Florida Palms West Hospital as a patient physically assaulted her and had to be restrained by deputies.

stories.headline: More roads closing in Northlake Blvd. area
stories.summary: Starting August 1, several roads in the Northlake Blvd. area will be temporarily closed due to a rail crossing upgrade by CSX. Northlake Boulevard at Beeline Highway will close from 8 p.m. until August 10 to facilitate the upgrades. Residents of Westlake, Loxahatchee Groves, and The Acreage will be affected by lane reductions and road closures. This is causing frustration as it impacts traffic and accessibility in the community.

stories.headline: Federal judge: Publix opioid case is settled
stories.summary: A federal judge has approved a settlement in the opioid case against Publix, claiming the supermarket chain's pharmacies overdosed opioid painkillers. While settlement terms were not publicly disclosed, the court's order indicated both sides agreed to resolve the dispute. Publix Director of Communications Maria Brois did not respond to requests for comment. The case had significant attention amid the broader opioid crisis litigation.
people: U.S. District Judge Michael L. Brown

stories.headline: Dolphins’ rookie quarterback Ewers earns Tua’s praise
stories.summary: Dolphins' rookie quarterback Anthony Ewers has earned praise from veteran quarterback Tua Tagovailoa for his performance and dedication. Ewers has shown promise in practice and games, contributing positively to the team's performance. This endorsement from Tua highlights Ewers' potential to be a valuable player for the Dolphins' future.

stories.headline: A little bit country
stories.summary: Lollapalooza festival in Chicago embraced a larger-than-life country music presence for the second year, featuring hybrid battery-powered stages and an emphasis on environmentally friendly power. Cowboy hats and boots were notably abundant, marking the festival's first-ever country music-focused day lineup with prominent female artists leading the charge.

stories.headline: Palestinian death toll rises as US envoy lands
stories.summary: US special envoy Steve Witkoff arrived in Israel to discuss the worsening humanitarian crisis in Gaza amid escalating violence. The article reports on meetings with Israeli and Palestinian leaders, including Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, about possible ceasefire and aid delivery. It highlights the growing death toll and humanitarian situation in Gaza as a major concern.

stories.headline: Field to succeed Davis grows
stories.summary: U.S. Representative Danny Davis announced he will not seek re-election and endorsed La Shawn Ford to succeed him. Ford is among several candidates aiming to take over the congressional district Davis has represented for almost 30 years. The article discusses Davis's decision amid his advancing age and the political implications for the next election cycle.

stories.headline: City’s air quality worst in world, at least for 1 day
stories.summary: Air quality alerts were issued in Illinois due to wildfire smoke making it the worst air quality day in the world in some locations. Experts warn that staying indoors isn't a perfect solution and discuss the health dangers posed by outdoor and indoor smoke exposure. The article covers the impact of Canadian wildfires on Chicago's air and public health advice.

stories.headline: Chicago hotels hitting a high note
stories.summary: With Lollapalooza's return to Grant Park, Chicago hotels and local restaurants are seeing a significant boost in business. Lollapalooza is described as one of downtown's most important events, drawing large crowds of visitors and impacting the hospitality sector positively this year.

stories.headline: Black rodeo entertains a sold-out crowd in KC
stories.summary: The Kansas City West Bottoms hosted its first Black rodeo in several years at the Hale Arena, drawing a sold-out crowd. The event featured traditional rodeo events with a focus on Black cowboy culture, including bull riding skills displayed by Lamarr Hankins. The rodeo included separate viewing areas for safety amidst the high-energy atmosphere. The Kansas City Star was granted exclusive access to document the event, which attracted rodeo lovers and first-time observers alike, celebrating the rich heritage and skills of Black cowboys.

stories.headline: Historic building to get new life as music-themed hotel
stories.summary: Plans are underway to redevelop a vacant historic building in downtown Kansas City into a music-themed hotel. BR Cos. of California first announced plans for the new high-rise apartment tower which will include more than 300 housing units and retail space, transforming the city's skyline. The project now adds the conversion of the Scarritt Building into the UMusic Hotel with 167 rooms, a performance venue, recording studios, and spaces dedicated to music-themed educational programs and experiential hotel properties inspired by music.

stories.headline: Community mourns fallen sheriff’s deputy in KCK
stories.summary: Hundreds gathered at the Wyandotte County Courthouse for a candlelight vigil to honor Deputy Elijah Ming, who was shot and killed while responding to a service call in Kansas City, Kansas. The community showed support and grief, with Kansas City Police Department Officer Carlos Ulloa expressing the shared family-like bond among officers. A memorial was decorated at the scene as mourners paid their respects to the nearly nine-year sheriff's department veteran.

stories.headline: ICE arrests workers at KC-area restaurants
stories.summary: Federal immigration agents raided at least two Kansas City-area Mexican restaurants late Wednesday morning, arresting at least 11 people, mostly Latino residents. The restaurants, El Toro Loco Mexican Bar and Grill and one in Lenexa, were closed with handwritten signs indicating the raids and arrests. Authorities locked down the premises, wrapped the silverware in napkins, and detained workers. Staff were escorted out in handcuffs amid tension and claims of intimidation from immigrant rights advocates.

stories.headline: Appeals court blocks Miami’s change to election date, finding it ‘unconstitutional’
stories.summary: Florida's Third District Court of Appeal blocked Miami's decision to postpone the November 2025 election to 2026 following legal challenges. The move was seen as unconstitutional because it conflicted with the city’s charter which mandates elections be held in odd-numbered years. The ruling favored a former city manager and city attorney statements emphasized the decision as a warning to corrupt politicians. The city will likely appeal the ruling to the Florida Supreme Court.

stories.headline: Feds investigating theft of game-worn gear worth ‘millions’ from Miami Heat’s home
stories.summary: A federal investigation was launched in early 2024 into the theft of game-worn memorabilia worth millions from the Miami Heat's home, including gear from high-profile players such as LeBron James, Shaquille O'Neal, and Dwyane Wade. The stolen items were taken over a multiyear period, and concerns include the sale of ill-gotten memorabilia. The investigation involves a retired Miami police officer and others who might have purchased or sold the stolen memorabilia in the largest known memorabilia heist in the country's history.

stories.headline: SINKING THEIR TEETH INTO IT: Miami’s grillz pioneer and his son keep smiles shining across generations
stories.summary: Orlando Plein, known as the original creator of the removable pull-out grillz, started his business in New York and opened a Miami store with his son Phillip Norville. The family business has become a cultural staple for those looking to wear decorative dental jewelry, either removable or permanent. Eddie Plein, Orlando’s brother, also played a significant role in popularizing grillz in New York and beyond, working with notable rappers. The Pleins continue to innovate and pass down skills within the family.

stories.headline: With millions at stake, Sergio Pino’s wife reaches key settlement in estate case
stories.summary: Tatiana Pino, wife of the late Coral Gables developer Sergio Pino, has reached a key settlement agreement involving millions of dollars in assets following a bitter divorce and legal dispute with Pino's family and company. The agreement was negotiated with the involvement of the FBI and related to ongoing federal court cases. Tatiana fortified her position in the estate case and related lawsuits, which involve multiple parties and claims over marital assets and trusts. The settlement will be presented to the Probate Judge for final approval.

stories.headline: U.S. Forest Service office in N.M. slated to be closed
stories.summary: Nine regional Forest Service offices across the country, including one in New Mexico, are planned to be phased out over the next year due to a reorganization plan by the U.S. Department of Agriculture. The local office likely will be absorbed as part of efforts to consolidate operations amidst changing regional hub structures.

stories.headline: WNMU regents say $1.9M buyout was illegal
stories.summary: The new board of regents at Western New Mexico University declared that a $1.9 million contract buyout authorized by the former governing board was illegal. The new regents cited violations of the state Open Meetings Act and took steps to terminate the previous agreement involving the university's former president.

stories.headline: New shelter operator moves in
stories.summary: Urban Alchemy has taken over management of Interfaith's old Pete’s Place homeless shelter, renaming it Agape House. The organization began deep cleaning the facility and hosted a farewell breakfast for volunteers, signaling a new chapter focused on improved operations and services for the homeless community in Santa Fe.

stories.headline: ‘We have learned to live with the pain’
stories.summary: Jude Voss and her family reflect on five years since the death of JB White, a promising 6-foot-7 Santa Fe High School basketball star. A gathering was held to celebrate White's birthday, blending memories with ongoing grief and the family's continued strength in coping with their loss.

stories.headline: In Montco, a legal battle over origins of TikTok
stories.summary: Two ex-contractors for Jeff Yass' Susquehanna International Group allege they were cut out of a profit-sharing deal involving TikTok's parent company, ByteDance. They claim Susquehanna quietly developed technology without their knowledge, cutting them out of a large investment deal. The legal battle centers on accusations of a "money grab" and involves extensive litigation, including a complex, winding dispute with substantial internal emails and documents. The trial will examine Suquehanna's involvement with ByteDance and the timing of their investment and alleged technology development.

stories.headline: Regional Rail riders may see fewer trains
stories.summary: Many Regional Rail riders could experience reduced service due to proposed SEPTA cuts starting August 24. This includes fewer weekday trips than currently scheduled, decreasing from 1,414 weekly trips to 960. The transit agency is facing budget challenges caused by financial crisis and state funding deficiencies. SEPTA is aiming to avoid low service levels and consider the effects on rush hour travel, which may be reduced from one hour to two hours during peak times.

stories.headline: Human composting? They're devoted to it, body and soil
stories.summary: Paul Meshejian, a 76-year-old retired actor, is an advocate for human composting—a process that is more eco-friendly than burial or cremation and converts human remains into nutrient-rich soil. While not yet legal in Pennsylvania, the process is gaining traction in neighboring states. Meshejian has arranged to be composted by the West Coast-based Earth Funeral, part of a network of companies that recycle compost bodies. Human composting appeals to those who want a sustainable and meaningful alternative to traditional burial methods.

stories.headline: World awaits fallout from tariff deadline
stories.summary: President Donald Trump signed an executive order imposing new penalties on several U.S. trading partners, effective in seven days. This is part of his ongoing trade agenda and follows recent tariff-related activities. The order affects negotiation timelines and trade frameworks, especially with Mexico and other nations, and has caused market uncertainty as the world prepares for potential economic impacts. The White House press secretary noted efforts to keep countries informed about these developments.

stories.headline: Cuts ahead for Fayette County Public Schools without new money
stories.summary: Fayette County Public Schools face a dire need for more funding to operate its large student district amidst projections of a $16 million deficit for fiscal year 2026. Deputy Superintendent Houston Barber said budget solutions are being explored, including asking FCPS to reconsider raising the occupational license tax. Without resolution, the district could experience layoffs, elimination of intervention programs, and declines in mental health support.

stories.headline: Gorton to seek historic third term
stories.summary: Lexington Mayor Linda Gorton announced she will seek a third and final term as the top elected official of Kentucky's second-largest city. Gorton expressed her love for the community and determination to improve it, noting progress made since her first year in 2019. Lexington’s mayoral race is nonpartisan with a May 19 primary deadline. Potential candidates include Raquel Carter, a real estate company owner, and Carter, a first-time candidate advocating for city growth. Gorton, now in her second term, has a history of public service including chairing the Board of Adjustment.

stories.headline: Epstein, Maxwell grand jury witnesses were all investigators
